summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The Government opposes Maxwell's ex parte application for a Rule 17(c) subpoena to the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP, arguing such subpoenas should not be used for discovery and requests notice of future subpoena applications and sharing of obtained materials.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The Government's letter is addressed to her, requesting orders regarding subpoena procedures.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case. The Government's letter concerns her defense team's application for a subpoena to obtain records from a law firm.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney who submitted the letter to the court, arguing against the defendant's subpoena application.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant in a criminal case over which Judge Nathan is presiding.
Strauss, as U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against defendant Maxwell.

events.title: Court Order on Subpoena Application
events.description: Judge Nathan issued an order regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's application for a subpoena to Boies Schiller Flexner LLP under Rule 17(c).

events.title: Government's Letter to Court
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office filed this letter opposing Maxwell's subpoena request and asking the court to mandate notice and sharing of materials from Rule 17(c) subpoenas.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The Government has produced over 2.7 million pages of discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense.

The Government is opposing Maxwell's attempt to subpoena records from the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP (BSF), arguing it is an improper 'fishing expedition' for impeachment material, not for admissible evidence.
The Government's letter reveals the BSF subpoena seeks sensitive victim information, including the 'original, complete copy' of a victim's diary.
The Government requests the court to order Maxwell's defense to provide notice of all Rule 17(c) subpoena applications and to share any obtained materials with the prosecution.
The legal argument centers on the strict standards from United States v. Nixon, which limit Rule 17(c) subpoenas to obtaining specific, admissible evidence for trial, not for general discovery.
